the history of various kinds

of films, they often
position Nanook of the North as being the first
documentary film historically.

And it's also been influential
among anthropologists in the social sciences
because many people saw it

as a precursor to
ethnographic film. And if you're not sure about
anthropology or ethnographic

So I mentioned in

from the time that you had the Lumiere
brothers inventing

their camera in the 1890s,
the early history of the film were very international
in origin.

So we talked about

the world, taking these films,

showing them to audiences. So from the very,
very beginning, it was a very international--

in the last class that you have to keep
in mind this was also the colonial period.

So this was really the height
of European colonialism. 1/3 of the landmass of the
globe during this period

was controlled by the
British in some form, either through direct colonies
or indirect protectorates.

Some people argue that 1/4
of the world's population were under some form
of British dominion. So between the various
major European powers--

and the US also had its
hands in some of this, but it was very much a
colonial international terrain.

And so you have to think about
the dissemination of cameras and early films in
that kind of context as they moved internationally.

And you also have to think
in the context of the US and Canada, you
also had internally colonized people
like Native Americans

many of you have talked

about this in basic
history classes elsewhere, but in the 19th
and 20th centuries

you might know that
ideas of social evolution were very common. Any sense of what those ideas
of social evolution were about?

stereotypes and ideas

were very pervasive

stereotypes then about non-western societies
were extremely negative.

the understandings

a romantic light,

countercurrent in European

more, quote-unquote, "primitive peoples" are

about Nanook of the North

out of this romantic, this romantic
primitive tradition.

why was this kind of Romantic
Primitivism so popular at the time? And Anna Grimshaw

films like Nanook and these kinds

that the First World

War was so deeply traumatic
for so many people that it caused them to
question the 19th century

strong faith in ideas of
science and technology as always leading to
greater rationality.

those kinds of ideas that society was just evolving
in this kind of upward way,

becoming more progressive, and that science and
technology were going to bring only wonderful things.

The first World War was
a very strong challenge for a lot of people. And she argues that there
were a couple of responses

to this, that surrealism, if you
think about other kinds of art movements like
surrealism and Dadaism were one kind of response,
because the surrealist ideas

of breaking down rationality
and focusing on dream states, for example, that was
one kind of response

to that kind of disillusionment. And she argues that
another response was a certain kind of romantic
primitivism, this idea, then,

that, well, these supposedly
primitive peoples were leading more simple authentic
lives and that they

didn't have to worry about
the horrors of modern warfare or the alienation
of modern life.

So there was this fascination
at that particular historical moment with these
kinds of groups.

focusing on what

were thought of at the time

romantic tradition

has historically focused
very strongly on nature. And there was often
expressed a kind

of longing for an untamed
nature and wild spaces, which was associated with the
fact that many of those spaces

were being transformed because
of colonialism or because of economic expansion. So there was often a kind of
nostalgia for certain kinds

of landscapes. So Nanook was a film that
brought both of those trends together, an interest
in a certain kind

of romantic primitivism
that was also tied to certain
kinds of nostalgia for certain kinds of
natural landscapes.
